body:
Meta-score is the wrong way to evaluate.

We need to get thread jumps in each of the benchmarks to where we would
expect (orthogonally to this, also syscall count).

Once we get there, meta score is about CPU throughput improvement and
contention improvement.
Until we get there anything we do might be undone by later changes.

On Wed, Oct 11, 2017 at 10:25 AM kpayson64 <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@kpayson64* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epoll1_linux.cc
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12943#discussion_r144079376>:
>
> > @@ -1228,6 +1284,7 @@ static const grpc_event_engine_vtable vtable = {
>      pollset_set_add_fd,
>      pollset_set_del_fd,
>
> +    workqueue_scheduler,
>
> This was just a POC so I could get some experimental numbers. In the case
> of epoll1 it looks like we would ignore the fd anyways.
>
> I didn't see much improvement (0.841 Meta-score).
>
